Award.AwardTitle: Deciphering QSOs: A New Approach for Measuring the Structures of their Central Engines
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to better understand quasar optical emission lines using a powerful new statistical tool - Independent Component Analysis (ICA) - which is capable of decomposing quasar spectra into linear combinations of independent spectral components that together make up the quasar gas. ICA will be applied to the large Sloan Digital Survey quasar sample to identify simple, rare types with just a few spectral components. These quasars will then be observed in the infrared using the SOAR telescope, and modeled using the CLOUDY computer code, to try to determine the physical nature of the emission line regions.

Broader impacts of the work include development of a new program to bring the STEM field subject of astronomy to outlying elementary schools in rural areas of Michigan, using a new portable planetarium. NSF funds will be used to send a professional planetarium lecturer around the state giving presentations, leaving behind a device for viewing the Sun, along with CDs with full sets of PowerPoint presentations and other materials. Twenty remote schools will be reached with this pilot program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Many distant galaxies have very strong emission lines in their spectra. The emission lines come from interstellar gas clouds within the galaxy in question, but are excited by ultraviolet photons emitted by either hot, recently-formed stars (a starburst) or by an active galactic nucleus (an “AGN", in which gas is being accreted onto a massive central black hole).

In this project, we developed and demonstrated a new statistical technique, called "Mean Field Independent Component Analysis" (MFICA), which breaks up the spectra of these galaxies into a series of physically significant different components. Then, for each individual galaxy, MFICA uses the mix of different components as a means for identifying the source of the exciting photons. This has allowed us to do a much better job of separating starburst galaxies from AGN than has previously been possible.

We have been using these pure samples to study the structure of the line-emitting gas within the different types of galaxies. We use a “Locally Optimally-emitting Cloud” model to describe the distribution of the interstellar gas, within each galaxy, as a huge sea of individual gas clouds. We then determine, for each galaxy, the distribution of these clouds in terms of their distances from the center of the galaxy and also their internal gas densities.  We are interested in seeing how these properties differ between starburst galaxies and AGN, and also how they change systematically within those two general classes of galaxies.

We have applied this analysis to a sample of thousands of galaxies taken from the catalogues of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey. The MFICA technique cleanly separates the sample into two distinct sequences: the starbursts and the AGN. Then within each of those two sequences MFICA shows that there is a progression from low-ionization to high-ionization starburst galaxies and AGN which is primarily due to a systematic change in the degree of central concentration of the radial distribution of the interstellar gas.
